items.title: Unable to get Optunity to work on Windows 10
items.body:
I have tried to get Optunity to work on two of my Windows 10 PCs without success.  I followed the instructions to install from GIT, added the PYTHONPATH to my System environment and also added the optunity folder to my  path.  However, optunity only works on the python files that are inside the optunity example folders.  I even tried to drag my own files that I need to process or tune with optunity, but then the python import call does not find the package.  Is there any way to have a more detailed windows direction with line-by-line steps that are more in line with a dummies like myself?  Thank you for your wonderful code and solution to the hyperparameter tuning 


here is a screen capture of two separate folders with the same code, where one recognizes the import and the other does not.
[Link to png sample setup](https://webzest.com/optunityissue.png)

items.title: Consuming large amount of disk space when using pmap
items.body: When I want to parallelly tune the hyper-parameters of my model, I tried to use `optunity.parallel.create_pmap` to create a pmap object to plug into the `optunity.maximize_structured` function. But it keeps consuming the disk space (almost 15GB). When I stopped the processes, the space recovered. I am not sure whether I use the parallel feature correctly.

items.title: create_pmap function not working as expected.
items.body:
I am running the:

```
pmap = optunity.parallel.create_pmap(24)
optimal_configuration, info, _ = optunity.maximize_structured(performance,
                                                              search_space=search,
                                                              pmap=pmap,
                                                              num_evals=500)
```
where the `search_space` has 5 algorithms.

As you know an `SVM` takes a lot longer to model than a `k-nn` this means that at first all 24 cores are used but they appear to then wait for the SVM to finish where only one core is used for the SVM when I would want all the cores to be then be split among the last SVM models. How can I do that?

items.title: How are particles initialized in PSO?
items.body: I went through the documents but couldn't find anything regarding the method implemented for particle initialization. Have you done this randomly or the particles are initialized from a particular distribution?

items.title: Patch to handle cross-validation when X is a sparse matrix
items.body:
Hi,

Thanks for the awesome package.  Optunity, by default, does not handle the case when X is sparse, since it tries to figure out the shape of X by calling len(X).

I added a small patch where I changed calls to len(X) with X.shape[0] which is valid even in the case where X is a scipy sparse matrix.

items.title: Support with Keras
items.body:
I'm trying to use optunity with [Keras](https://github.com/fchollet/keras). Can that be done? I'm trying like:

```
@optunity.cross_validated(x=x_t, y=y_t, num_folds=2, num_iter=2)
def svm_auc(x_train, y_train, x_test, y_test, mom):
    #model = sklearn.svm.SVC(C=10 ** logC, gamma=10 ** logGamma).fit(x_train, y_train)
    sgd = SGD(lr=0.1, decay=1e-6, momentum=mom, nesterov=True)
    model.compile(loss='mean_squared_error', optimizer=sgd, class_mode="binary")
    decision_values = model.predict(x_train)
    #return optunity.metrics.roc_auc(y_train, decision_values)
    return model.predict(x_test, y_test)
mom = optunity.minimize(svm_auc, num_evals=200, mom=[0.01, 0.99]) 
```

items.title: Unexpected working of maximize_structured function when using multiple arguments
items.body:
I would like to optimize features' weight and classifier's parameters at the same time using maximize_structured function. I specified search space as below (F1 corresponds to the first feature. In this case, there are 11 features to optimize their weight), and used it in the maximize_structured function. However, after the optimization of first iteration, arguments changed like below, which just returns 'None' for 'weight' argument and optimizes just  'algorithm' arguments. I expected that all parameters of 'weight' argument (i.e. F1-F11) are optimized as well.  How can I optimize 'weight' at the same time with optimization for classifier?

```
self.search=
{'algorithm': {'SVM': {'kernel': {'linear': {'C': [-5, 2]},
                                  'poly': {'C': [-5, 2],
                                           'coef0': [0, 1],
                                           'degree': [2, 5]},
                                  'rbf': {'C': [-5, 2], 'gamma': [-5, 2]}}},
               'naive-bayes': None,
               'random-forest': {'max_features': [2, 1096],
                                 'n_estimators': [10, 30]}},
 'weight': {'F1': [1, 10],
            'F10': [1, 10],
            'F11': [1, 10],
            'F2': [1, 10],
            'F3': [1, 10],
            'F4': [1, 10],
            'F5': [1, 10],
            'F6': [1, 10],
            'F7': [1, 10],
            'F8': [1, 10],
            'F9': [1, 10]}}
```

This is the arguments that I got inside the performance function.

```
kargs
{'C': 0.88232421875,
 'F1': None,
 'F10': None,
 'F11': None,
 'F2': None,
 'F3': None,
 'F4': None,
 'F5': None,
 'F6': None,
 'F7': None,
 'F8': None,
 'F9': None,
 'algorithm': 'SVM',
 'coef0': 0.04931640625,
 'degree': 3.49853515625,
 'gamma': None,
 'kernel': 'poly',
 'max_features': None,
 'n_estimators': None}
```

Here is the code where I use the search space and get the arguments 'kargs'.

```
@optunity.cross_validated(x=self.xtrain, y=self.ytrain, num_folds=num_folds, num_iter=num_iter)
def performance(x_train, y_train, x_test, y_test,**kargs):
    xtrain,xtest=setWeight(xtrain,xtest,**kargs)
    model,_=setModel(**kargs)
    model.fit(x_train, y_train)
    # predict the test set
    if kargs['algorithm'] == 'SVM':
        predictions = model.decision_function(x_test)
    else:
        predictions = model.predict_proba(x_test)[:, 1]
    return optunity.metrics.roc_auc(y_test, predictions)

optimal_configuration, info, optimal_pars3 = optunity.maximize_structured(performance,search_space=self.search,num_evals=num_evals)
```

    118             seed = self.seed if self.seed else random.randint(0, 9999999999)
--> 119             return hyperopt.tpe.suggest(_args, seed=seed *_kwargs)
    120 
    121         space = [hyperopt.hp.uniform(k, v[0], v[1]) for k, v in self.bounds.items()]

items.title: Incompatibility with scikit-learn
items.body: As explained here: http://stackoverflow.com/q/30539388/2148672

items.title: Optimize class weights
items.body:
Is it possible to tune a classifier's class weight vector using optunity?

Currently the parameter space is defined in optunity's 'minimize' and 'maximize' by passing it the lower and upper bounds. This assumes the parameter is a single number (such as 'C' or 'gamma'). I am wondering whether it is possible to optimize a weight vector, for example, where the length of the vector equals the number of classes. 

Thanks

items.title: handling of discrete hyperparameters
items.body:
Hi,

I'd like to know if it is possible to use optunity to find hyperparameter solutions, when these parameters are discrete.

Then is it possible with non-ordinal hyperparameters ?

Finally, if it is not possible, do you plan to implement it and in case the answer is affirmative, for when ?

items.title: usage of identity in cross-validation
items.body:
I am getting the following error by setting the aggregator option to opt.cross_validation.identity

```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
     33 # Define Parameter Tuning
---> 34 optimal_pars_clf_sgd, _, _ = opt.maximize(clf_sgd_cv, num_evals=n_hyperparams_evals, alpha=[0.001, .1], l1_ratio=[0., 1.])
     35 
     36 # Train model on the Inner Training Set with Tuned Hyperparameters

../local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/optunity/api.pyc in maximize(f, num_evals, solver_name, pmap, **kwargs)
    179     solver = make_solver(**suggestion)
    180     solution, details = optimize(solver, f, maximize=True, max_evals=num_evals,
--> 181                                  pmap=pmap)
    182     return solution, details, suggestion
    183 

../local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/optunity/api.pyc in optimize(solver, func, maximize, max_evals, pmap)
    243     time = timeit.default_timer()
    244     try:
--> 245         solution, report = solver.optimize(f, maximize, pmap=pmap)
    246     except fun.MaximumEvaluationsException:
    247         # early stopping because maximum number of evaluations is reached

../local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/optunity/solvers/ParticleSwarm.pyc in optimize(self, f, maximize, pmap)
    257             fitnesses = pmap(evaluate, list(map(self.particle2dict, pop)))
    258             for part, fitness in zip(pop, fitnesses):
--> 259                 part.fitness = fit*fitness
    260                 if not part.best or part.best_fitness < part.fitness:
    261                     part.best = part.position

TypeError: can't multiply sequence by non-int of type 'float'
```

Here is my code 

```
import optunity as opt
from optunity.metrics import _recall, contingency_table
from sklearn.linear_model import SGDClassifier
import numpy as np

n_in = 1
k_in = 2
n_hyperparams_evals = 10

clf_sgd = SGDClassifier(
            penalty="elasticnet",
            shuffle=True,
            n_iter=500,
            fit_intercept=True,
            learning_rate="optimal")

# Define Inner CV
cv_decorator = opt.cross_validated(x=X, y=Y.values, 
                                   num_folds=k_in, num_iter=n_in,
                                   strata=[Y[Y==1].index.values], 
                                   regenerate_folds=True,
                                   aggregator=opt.cross_validation.identity)

def obj_fun_clf_sgd(x_train, y_train, x_test, y_test, alpha, l1_ratio):
    model = clf_sgd.set_params(l1_ratio=l1_ratio, alpha=alpha).fit(x_train, y_train)
    y_pred = model.predict(x_test)
    score = _recall(contingency_table(y_test,y_pred))
    return score

clf_sgd_cv = cv_decorator(obj_fun_clf_sgd)

# Define Parameter Tuning
optimal_pars_clf_sgd, _, _ = opt.maximize(clf_sgd_cv, num_evals=n_hyperparams_evals, alpha=[0.001, .1], l1_ratio=[0., 1.])

# Train model on the Inner Training Set with Tuned Hyperparameters
optimal_model_clf_sgd = clf_sgd.set_params(**optimal_pars_clf_sgd).fit(X, Y.values)
```

The objective is to keep track of all the scores from the various folds. Is it a bug? or am I using incorrectly the API ?

Thanks in advance

items.title: Random search leaves bounds in maximize()
items.body: Random search seems to ignore bounds. The problem is either in `suggest_from_box` or the static key order used in function evaluation.

items.title: Better example for CV
items.body:
In the doc the first CV example returns 0.0. Maybe we could have a more practical example there?
http://optunity.readthedocs.org/en/latest/user/cross_validation.html

``` python
@opt.cross_validated(x=data, y=labels, num_folds=3)
def cved(x_train, y_train, x_test, y_test):
    train(x_train, y_train)
    predict(x_test)
    return 0.0

cved()
```

items.title: maximize uses wrong default value if constraints are violated
items.body:
In optunity/api.py line 176 sys.float_info.min is set as default:

> f = _wrap_hard_box_constraints(f, kwargs, sys.float_info.min)

However, sys.float_info.min is the "minimum positive normalized float" [1] which evaluates to 2.2250738585072014e-308 in my case. This causes maximize to to choose parameters that violate constraints if something like a negative mean squared error should be maximized. I suggest to replace this line by:

> f = _wrap_hard_box_constraints(f, kwargs, -sys.float_info.max)

[1] https://docs.python.org/2/library/sys.html#sys.float_info

items.title: PR curve computation is not correct
items.body: In some cases PR curves are incorrect.

octave:1> optunity_example
error: 'optunity' undefined near line 5 column 11

Al the relevant folders in the optunity directory are in Octave's path environment. Any suggestions?

items.title: Optunity's score functions are not entirely sklearn compatible
items.body: sklearn has a tendency of returning numpy stuff, which in turn have a tendency not to iterate as one might expect.

items.title: Optunity build broken
items.body: Not sure what happened but builds suddenly broke on both travis & rtd. Needs fixing ASAP (tomorrow).

items.title: nosetests misses doctests in top-level optunity modules
items.body: Currently nosetests only runs the tests in optunity/solvers/. For some reason those in optunity/ are being ignored.

items.title: Catch and send optunity.piped errors
items.body:
The following list of errors should be caught at the highest level:
- TypeError
- ValueError

items.title: generating cv folds does not work with 1 stratum
PSO doesn't use the entire evaluation budget
items.body: PSO solver sometimes stops early, with less function evaluations than we allow.

items.title: lambda cannot be used as an input name
items.body:
A python problem: **lambda** is a reserved keyword. Would be nice to have a workaround. For at least API calls.

```
echo '{"optimize" : {"max_evals": 0}, "solver": {"solver_name" : "grid search", "lambda":[0,10]}}' | python -m optunity.piped
Exception in thread FutureThread:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/threading.py", line 810, in __bootstrap_inner
    self.run()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/threading.py", line 763, in run
    self.__target(*self.__args, **self.__kwargs)
  File "optunity/parallel.py", line 131, in Wrapper
    self.__result=func(*param)
  File "optunity/communication.py", line 157, in wrap
    result = f(*args)
  File "optunity/functions.py", line 357, in wrapped_f
    return f(**dict([(k, v) for k, v in zip(keys, args)]))
  File "optunity/functions.py", line 232, in wrapped_f
    wrapped_f.argtuple = collections.namedtuple('args', wrapped_f.keys)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/collections.py", line 334, in namedtuple
    'keyword: %r' % name)
ValueError: Type names and field names cannot be a keyword: 'lambda'
```

items.title: particle-swarm doc should give example of kwargs use
items.body:
http://optunity.readthedocs.org/en/latest/api/optunity.solvers.html#optunity.solvers.ParticleSwarm

Might be useful to have an example of ParticleSwarm. Mainly for showing that the contents of kwargs is box constraints (currently there is also no comment about kwargs under ParticleSwarm).

items.title: running optunity on windows
items.body:
We checked Windows setup with Dusan and found out there is an issue:
- the Python installation in Windows does not put python.exe into the system path
- however, it links .py files to python, so running any .py file will work

So `python -m optunity.piped` will not work in Windows, but a simple solution is to call optunity.piped from a separate script:
1. make optunity.piped's main code into a separate method (currently it is just under `if __name__=='__main__'`), like explained here http://www.artima.com/weblogs/viewpost.jsp?thread=4829
2. then create a script in the top folder that launches the new main method, e.g. run.py:

``` python
#!/usr/bin/env python
import optunity.piped
optunity.piped.main()
```

Then we will just execute run.py in Windows (or also in other systems). Note: shebang is ignored in Windows.

@claesenm if the solution looks fine to you let me know, I can easily do the implementation or you can do it :).

items.title: piped make_solver error on "random search"
items.body:
An error with make_solver and random search. Expecting instead a JSON message.

``` bash
echo '{"make_solver":{"solver_name":"random search"}}' | python -m optunity.piped
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/runpy.py", line 162, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", fname, loader, pkg_name)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/runpy.py", line 72, in _run_code
    exec code in run_globals
  File "/home/jaak/git/optunity/optunity/piped.py", line 482, in <module>
    make_solver(startup_msg['make_solver'])
  File "/home/jaak/git/optunity/optunity/piped.py", line 389, in make_solver
    optunity.make_solver(**solver_config)
  File "optunity/api.py", line 282, in make_solver
    return solvercls(*args, **kwargs)
TypeError: __init__() takes exactly 2 arguments (1 given)
```

When using **grid search** the make_solver works:

``` bash
echo '{"make_solver":{"solver_name":"grid search"}}' | python -m optunity.piped
{"success": "true"}
```

items.title: Error in optunity.piped with maximize and grid search
items.body:
When running 'grid search' from command line gives error when 'random search' works.

**Grid search**

``` bash
echo '{"maximize" : {"solver_name" : "grid search", "num_evals": 5, "x":[0,10]} }' | python -m optunity.piped
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/runpy.py", line 162, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", fname, loader, pkg_name)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/runpy.py", line 72, in _run_code
    exec code in run_globals
  File "/home/jaak/git/optunity/optunity/piped.py", line 495, in <module>
    startup_msg.get('call_log', None))
  File "/home/jaak/git/optunity/optunity/piped.py", line 421, in max_or_min
    solution, rslt, solver = solve_fun(func, pmap=mgr.pmap, **kwargs)
  File "optunity/api.py", line 172, in maximize
    pmap=pmap)
  File "optunity/api.py", line 245, in optimize
    optimum = f.call_log[t(**solution)]
TypeError: __new__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'x'
```

**Random search (works)**

``` bash
echo '{"maximize" : {"solver_name" : "random search", "num_evals": 5, "x":[0,10]} }' | python -m optunity.piped
[{"x": 4.90398335468162}, {"x": 2.9585346492371967}, {"x": 8.75973165625038}, {"x": 0.934354531998024}, {"x": 5.092791699936537}]
{"error_msg": "Broken pipe."}
```

http://optunity.readthedocs.org/en/latest/api/optunity.piped.html#optimize

items.title: writing to named pipe in windows with python
items.body:
In Linux/mac we have a solution `python -m optunity > /tmp/py2r`. However, Windows does not support that (http://superuser.com/questions/430466/in-windows-can-i-redirect-stdout-to-a-named-pipe-in-command-line).

So an option is to pass the name of the pipe to python with a paramater, like:

``` bash
python -m optunity.piped -p py2r
```

And in python use

``` python
f = open(r'\\.\pipe\py2r', 'w', 0)
...
f.write(...)
```

This would be only used in windows. Seems like the easiest approach or are there other options?

items.title: Implement Nelder-Mead solver without dependency to numpy/scipy
IPython crashes with optunity.parallel.pmap
items.body:
IPython crashes if the parallelized function outputs anything to stdout or stderr. This is an IPython issue that we can't fix ourselves. 

More info at: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/2438/

A workaround is to use IPython's own parallel features:
http://nbviewer.ipython.org/github/vals/scilife-python-course/blob/master/parallel%20python.ipynb

items.title: make optunity.piped use concurrent.future
items.body:
optunity.piped works but uses way too many resources currently when doing vector evaluations (1 thread per evaluation, solvers like grid search can easily have thousands ...). Need to use concurrent.future backport in 2.x

cfr. http://stackoverflow.com/a/8797256/2148672

items.title: update optunity.piped and matlab wrapper for new api
nested cross-validation
support for vector evaluations
DEAP integration
items.body:
Include DEAP in the Optunity package and automate code conversion from 2 to 3 on install (setup.py).

Note: the fact DEAP needs 2 to 3 conversion may cause issues for non-Python users (e.g. in wrappers).

items.body: Remove all traces of numpy dependency from optunity._cross_validation.
